article.para: The xmldb module (http://exist-db.org/xquery/xmldb function namespace) contains functions for manipulating database contents. The full list of functions and their documentation can be found in the Function Documentation Library. This article handles some of the highlights and main uses for this module.

sect1.title: Specifying the Input Document Set
sect1.para: A database can contain a virtually unlimited set of collections and documents. Four functions are available to restrict the input document set to a user-defined set of documents or collections: doc(), collection(), xmldb:document(), and xmldb:xcollection(). The first two are standard XPath functions, the others eXist-db specific extensions.
The differences between the XPath and the eXist-db specific functions are:

listitem.para: While doc() is restricted to a single document-URI argument, xmldb:document() accepts multiple document paths to be included into the input node set.
Calling xmldb:document() without an argument includes every document in the database.
The collection() function specifies the collection of documents to be included in the query evaluation. By default, documents found in sub-collections of the specified collection are also included.

For example, suppose we have a collection /db/test that contains two sub-collections /db/test/abc and /db/test/def. In this case, the function call collection('/db/test') will include all of the resources found in /db/test, /db/test/abc and /db/test/def.
The function xmldb:xcollection() does not include sub-collections.

This references a resource relative to the base URI property defined in the static XQuery context. This contains an XML:DB URI pointing to the base collection (see below) for the current query context, for instance xmldb:exist:///db.

sect1.para: The base collection depends on how the query context was initialized. If you call a query via the XML:DB API, the base collection is the collection from which the query service was obtained. All relative URLs will be resolved relative to that collection. If a stored query is executed via REST, the base collection is the collection in which the XQuery source resides. In most other cases, the base collection will point to the database root /db.

note.para: As it might not always be clear what the base collection is, we recommend to always use absolute paths. This allows using the query with different interfaces.
